latest news.eng_title: NASA Was 'Right' To Bring Starliner Back Empty As Thrusters And Guidance Fail On Return
latest news.summary: NASA's decision to leave astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams on the International Space Station due to issues with Boeing's Starliner spacecraft has been vindicated after the craft's return to Earth. The Starliner experienced a failed thruster and temporary guidance system blackout during re-entry, raising questions about its safety. NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said, 'I think we made the right decision not to have Butch and Suni on board.' The issues with Starliner's thrusters, which failed during docking with the ISS, and overheating problems have led to a chasm between NASA and Boeing, with NASA viewing the data and uncertainty differently than Boeing. The next Starliner launch, scheduled for August 2025, is now uncertain due to the ongoing concerns about Boeing's space flight ambitions.
latest news.title: NASA Was 'Right' To Bring Starliner Back Empty As Thrusters And Guidance Fail On Return

latest news.eng_title: What Starliner's crewless return means for NASA and Boeing
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner space capsule returned to Earth without its crew on September 7, 2024, after a test flight to the International Space Station was aborted due to thruster failures. The capsule's remotely piloted return marked the end of a fraught test flight that left astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita 'Suni' Williams on the station for months longer than intended. According to Michael Fossum, former commander of the ISS, NASA's decision to return the craft uncrewed means that the agency will continue to have multiple options for getting crew members to and from the space station, including its partnership with Russia and the SpaceX Dragon crew spacecraft. Fossum believes that Boeing's reputation will suffer due to the failure, but that the company will continue to play a role in NASA's Commercial Crew Program. The extended stay of Wilmore and Williams on the ISS will require NASA to increase deliveries of food, clothing, and other supplies to the station. Fossum notes that human spaceflight is 'excruciatingly hard and relentlessly unforgiving,' and that setbacks and failures are a normal part of the process. He expresses optimism about the future of human spaceflight, citing the progress made in recent years and the upcoming Artemis II mission.
latest news.title: What Starliner's crewless return means for NASA and Boeing

latest news.eng_title: What Starliner's crewless return means for NASA and Boeing Premium
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner space capsule returned to Earth without its crew on September 7, 2024, after a test flight to the International Space Station. The capsule's thruster failures made it unsafe to pilot back, leaving astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita 'Suni' Williams on the station for months longer than intended. NASA has expressed support for Boeing, but experts believe the company's reputation will suffer due to the setback. The Starliner program is still in development, and NASA has multiple options for crew transport, including SpaceX's Dragon capsule. The extended stay of Wilmore and Williams on the space station has caused a ripple effect, with increased demand for food, clothing, and other supplies. NASA has started increasing deliveries on cargo ships to accommodate the larger crew. Despite the setback, NASA is optimistic about the future of human spaceflight, with multiple programs underway, including the SpaceX Crew Dragon, Boeing Starliner, and NASA's Orion spacecraft for the Artemis II mission.
latest news.title: What Starliner's crewless return means for NASA and Boeing Premium

latest news.eng_title: Is There a Future for Starliner After Failed Mission?
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, which was intended to ferry crews to the International Space Station (ISS), has failed in its first crewed mission. The spacecraft landed safely in New Mexico without crew on September 6, after NASA decided to cancel the mission due to thruster problems and leaks in the helium system. Boeing executives have expressed pride in the spacecraft's performance, but NASA is being cautious, citing the need to investigate the cause of the failure. The Starliner program has been plagued by delays and cost overruns, with Boeing taking an additional $1.6 billion in charges over the life of the program. NASA may decide to cancel the program altogether, given the rising costs and the fact that SpaceX has successfully launched 13 crewed missions since 2020. 'We're on contract for seven or six flights,' said Mark Nappi, manager of Boeing's commercial crew program. 'That carries us out to the end of the decade, and so we've got plenty of time to think about what's after that.' However, the ticking clock and rising costs may make it difficult for Boeing to fix the Starliner's thruster problems and ensure its future in the ISS program.
latest news.title: Is There a Future for Starliner After Failed Mission?

latest news.eng_title: TechCrunch Space: Boeing's Starliner returns to Earth
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner capsule has successfully returned to Earth from the International Space Station, landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. The capsule returned autonomously without its two crew members, NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who will remain on the station until next February. NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich described the flight as 'darn near flawless,' but expressed mixed feelings among staff. The agency had planned to have the mission land with the crew on board. Meanwhile, NASA has postponed the ESCAPADE mission to Mars, citing potential cost and technical issues with de-fueling the two satellites. The mission was originally scheduled to launch in October 2024, but will now take place in spring 2025. Additionally, NASA astronaut Frank Culbertson was the only American off-world when the September 11 terrorist attacks occurred, and captured images of the site from the International Space Station.
latest news.title: TechCrunch Space: Boeing's Starliner returns to Earth

latest news.eng_title: New Issues for Boeing Starliner Emerge During Descent
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, designed to transport astronauts to and from the International Space Station (ISS), has experienced technical issues during its return to Earth. Despite a 'bullseye landing,' the spacecraft suffered a failed control thruster and a temporary blackout of the navigation system during reentry. NASA's Steve Stich said, 'We did learn a lot, and although we had hoped to have astronauts onboard, we made the right decision in bringing the capsule back uncrewed.' The thruster issue highlighted ongoing concerns that had already plagued the spacecraft earlier in the mission. NASA and Boeing engineers are now tasked with addressing the critical issues that emerged during the mission, including the thruster problems and helium leaks. Boeing has already absorbed significant financial losses as part of its Starliner program, with more than $1.6 billion in recorded charges due to cost overruns and delays. The company's struggles in the space sector add to a growing list of challenges for Boeing, whose commercial aircraft division has also been hit hard by production issues and accidents. NASA remains cautiously optimistic about the future of the Starliner program, but the agency acknowledges the need for substantial improvements before the spacecraft can be certified for operational crewed missions.
latest news.title: New Issues for Boeing Starliner Emerge During Descent

latest news.eng_title: Troubled Boeing Starliner spacecraft gets a return date as NASA shuffles Crew-9
latest news.summary: NASA has given Boeing's troubled Starliner spacecraft a return date, with plans to undock from the International Space Station no earlier than 6:04 p.m. ET on Friday, Sept. 6. After undocking, it will land at approximately 12:03 a.m. on Saturday, Sept. 7, at White Sands Space Harbor. However, NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who were supposed to return on the spacecraft, will instead remain on the space station until February 2025 and return on a SpaceX Dragon. NASA's main concern with Starliner was the reliability of its thrusters upon reentry, which could have put the crew in danger. Boeing has work to do once Starliner lands, as NASA remains optimistic the aerospace company will still be able to provide a full crewed flight in the future.
latest news.title: Troubled Boeing Starliner spacecraft gets a return date as NASA shuffles Crew-9

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Can't Bring Back the Stranded Starliner Astronauts Home. Now SpaceX Must Rescue Them.
news knowledge.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft has failed to meet NASA's safety and performance requirements for human spaceflight, forcing the agency to cancel the crew's return to Earth and instead rely on SpaceX to rescue them. The astronauts, Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, will remain on the International Space Station until at least February 2025. NASA has decided not to allow the astronauts to fly on Starliner again due to the spacecraft's persistent problems with sticky valves and helium leaks. Boeing is now faced with a dilemma: either abandon the Starliner program and take a huge charge to earnings, or try to get the spacecraft back on track and risk further failure. The clock is ticking, as the ISS is slated for decommissioning after 2030, and there may not be enough time left to conduct more than three or four operational missions with Starliner.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Can't Bring Back the Stranded Starliner Astronauts Home. Now SpaceX Must Rescue Them.

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner Crew Flight Test Will End September 6
news knowledge.summary: NASA has decided to end the Boeing Starliner Crew Flight Test mission on September 6, with the spacecraft returning to Earth empty instead of bringing back the two NASA astronauts who were aboard. The decision was made due to concerns about the thrusters' performance, which experienced helium leaks and thruster failures during the mission. The astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, will remain on the International Space Station and return on the next scheduled crew rotation mission using SpaceX's Crew Dragon in February 2025. Boeing will bear the cost of the necessary fixes, which is estimated to be around $1.6 billion. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson expressed confidence that Starliner will fly again with a crew, and the ISS has a 'lifeboat' available in case of an emergency. The Crew-8 Crew Dragon and Soyuz MS-25 will be docked at the ISS after Starliner leaves, and a handover will take place with Crew-9 before they depart.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Starliner Crew Flight Test Will End September 6

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing's Starliner Faces Uncertain Future as NASA Considers Cancellation
news knowledge.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft is facing an uncertain future due to technical issues, delays, and budget overruns. The spacecraft, once a critical component of NASA's Commercial Crew program, is now at risk of cancellation. According to a report by Reuters, the project has exceeded its budget by $1.6 billion since 2016. Former NASA deputy administrator Lori Garver expressed uncertainty about the project's future, stating, 'I am not sure the decision will ultimately be NASA's. Boeing is going to have to foot much of this bill, as they have been.' A Boeing spokesperson did not directly address the possibility of cancellation, focusing instead on the safety of the crew and spacecraft. The failure of Starliner's first crewed test flight has denied NASA the confidence it needs to certify the spacecraft for regular crew rotation missions to the International Space Station. Analysts have suggested that Boeing may ultimately exit the Commercial Crew program due to its complexity and the superior performance of its competitor, SpaceX. Melius Research analyst Robert Spingarn told Bloomberg, 'Do they ultimately exit the program because it's too complicated and because the other guy can do it better? It can happen.'
news knowledge.title: Boeing's Starliner Faces Uncertain Future as NASA Considers Cancellation

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA Abandons Boeing's Starliner, Astronauts to Return on SpaceX Crew Dragon
news knowledge.summary: NASA has decided to cancel the manned return flight of Boeing's Starliner spacecraft due to technical issues. The two astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, have been stranded on the International Space Station (ISS) for weeks. NASA has announced that they will instead return to Earth on a SpaceX Crew Dragon, which is scheduled for February 2025. The decision was made after a press conference, where NASA officials stated that there was 'too much uncertainty' about the reliability of the Starliner's engines. The agency will now attempt to return the spacecraft to Earth on an unmanned test flight in October, with a simplified separation method. NASA's decision is seen as a major setback for Boeing, which has already invested billions of dollars in the Starliner program. As Steve Stich, the program leader, said, 'We are changing the planned separation sequence. We will use a simplified separation method to get us off the station faster.'
news knowledge.title: Größtmögliche Blamage: NASA tauscht Boeings Starliner gegen SpaceX

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA: Boeing Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew
news knowledge.summary: NASA has decided to return the Boeing-made Starliner spacecraft to Earth without its crew, citing safety concerns. The decision comes after a test flight in June, which suffered damage upon docking at the International Space Station. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson said, 'Spaceflight is risky, even at its safest and most routine. A test flight, by nature, is neither safe, nor routine.' The spacecraft experienced helium leaks and thruster problems during its maiden voyage. NASA and Boeing officials will continue to gather data and improve the system for future flights. Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will remain on the International Space Station until at least February 2025, helping with experiments and gathering more data on the Starliner's performance. 'Starliner is a very capable spacecraft, but we need a higher level of certainty to perform a crewed return,' said Steve Stich, manager of NASA's Commercial Crew Program.
news knowledge.title: NASA: Boeing Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA Cancels Boeing Starliner Return Flight Due to Safety Concerns
news knowledge.summary: The NASA has decided to cancel the return flight of the Boeing Starliner spacecraft due to safety concerns. The spacecraft's propulsion system has been deemed too risky for a manned return flight. As a result, astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will have to stay on the International Space Station (ISS) until a SpaceX crewed mission in February 2025. Their original mission was supposed to last eight days, but it will now last eight months. According to Norm Knight, a NASA spokesperson, 'Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams completely support the agency's decision and are ready to continue their mission on the ISS.' This decision adds to Boeing's troubled history, which has been plagued by issues with its commercial aircraft. The failure of this test flight confirms SpaceX's dominance in the space industry, as the company has been providing crewed missions for the past four years.
news knowledge.title: Deux astronautes d'une mission de Boeing reviendront sur Terre avec... SpaceX en février

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA Cancels Starliner's Return to Earth with Astronauts on Board
news knowledge.summary: The NASA has decided to cancel the Starliner spacecraft's return to Earth with astronauts on board. Instead, the spacecraft will return empty to the Earth in September. The decision was made after a review of the Starliner's performance, which included five helium leaks and five failed thrusters during a recent flight. 'There was too much uncertainty with the thrusters,' said Steve Stitch, director of the NASA's Commercial Crew Program. 'It was too much risk with crew, so we decided to do uncrewed tests.' The Starliner's return to Earth will be delayed until September, while the Crew-9 mission with SpaceX will be rescheduled for no earlier than September 24. The two astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, will travel to the International Space Station on a SpaceX Crew Dragon and stay for 10 months. Boeing is still defending the Starliner's ability to return safely to Earth, despite the recent issues.
news knowledge.title: La decisión está tomada: SpaceX rescatará a los astronautas de la NASA y la nave de Boeing volverá vacía

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA Considers Options for Returning Starliner with Astronauts on Board
news knowledge.summary: The Boeing Starliner, a spacecraft built for NASA's Commercial Crew Program, has been stuck at the International Space Station (ISS) since June 6, 2024, due to technical issues. The spacecraft was initially intended to return to Earth with astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, but NASA is now considering two options: repairing the spacecraft and allowing the astronauts to pilot it back to Earth, or returning it to Earth without the crew. The first option is considered riskier, as the spacecraft may experience new issues on a second crewed flight. If the second option is chosen, Wilmore and Williams will have to stay on the ISS until February 2025, when they can catch a ride on a SpaceX flight. The prolonged stay on the ISS poses significant health risks to the astronauts, including radiation exposure, bone loss, and vision problems. NASA is conducting a Flight Readiness Review, involving three independent technical agencies, to determine the feasibility of returning the Starliner with the astronauts on board. The review will present recommendations to NASA's Associate Administrator for Space Operations, Ken Bowersox, who will make the final decision. Emily Nelson, NASA's Chief of Flight, said, 'Before each major milestone, especially on a test flight, we do a complete review of readiness.' The decision is expected to be made by the end of August 2024.
news knowledge.title: Nasa apresenta duas propostas de resgate para astronautas presos no espaço

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA Confirms Crew-9 Launch Date and Postpones Starliner's First Operational Flight
news knowledge.summary: NASA has confirmed that the launch of the Crew-9 mission to the International Space Station (ISS) is scheduled for no earlier than August 18. The announcement was made during a press conference, following a recent anomaly with the Falcon 9 rocket. SpaceX has resolved the issue (caused by a crack in a sensor line that allowed liquid oxygen to escape), making modifications to both the hardware and software of the rocket. According to Steve Stich, NASA's commercial crew program manager, the launch will depend on a test of the new upper stage. The modifications will be strictly certified before being approved for the Crew-9 mission. The launch of Crew-9 must take place within the first days of September to prepare Launch Complex 39A for the Europa Clipper mission with the Falcon Heavy, scheduled for October. Crew-9 consists of NASA astronauts Zena Cardman, Nick Hague, Stephanie Wilson, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Alexsandr Gorbunov. Meanwhile, the first operational flight of the Boeing Starliner spacecraft, initially scheduled for February 2025, has been postponed to August 2025. This period will allow NASA and Boeing to analyze the data from the Crew Flight Test (CFT) mission and implement any necessary modifications.
news knowledge.title: Spazio: la NASA conferma il lancio di Crew-9 ad agosto, rinviato il primo volo operativo di Starliner

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner, 50 says after launching, remains without return date as testing continues
news knowledge.summary: The Boeing Starliner Crew Flight Test, which launched on June 5, remains without a set return date due to thruster malfunctions and helium leaks. NASA's Commercial Crew Program manager, Steve Stich, stated that they are making progress but are not yet ready to announce a return date. The mission was originally planned to be eight days, but NASA and Boeing continued to push back the return date to investigate the issues. Mark Nappi, vice president and program manager for Boeing's Commercial Crew Program, believes that part of the problem was the deformation of Teflon seals due to high heat. Nappi regrets being too specific about the mission's timeline and wishes they had been more flexible.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Starliner, 50 says after launching, remains without return date as testing continues
